job_title: Clinical Research Recruiter in San Francisco, CA
pros: Loved my boss. Loved meeting new people. Loved being a part of meaningful work. Was flexible.
cons: Hours are wonky because you need to recruit when and wherever there were events that attracted the demographic. Pay was comparable to other recruiter jobs, and it is an underfunded non-profit, but for the area is just a low hourly wage for anyone working for more than pocket change. The low pay causes a frustrating amount of turn over.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Instructional Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: I love that the job itself is very flexible. I get to set my own hours and work when I want. For me as a current student that makes a whole world of difference. Specifically this summer I loved all of the opportunities that were provided to me by the Campus Rec department of SFSU. This summer I had the opportunity to network with other people through a NIRSA workshop as well as grow my skills through class provided at our facility. I love that I am apart of a team who supports my growth as a student, a professional and an individual.
cons: I wish that I had the opportunity to see my family more this summer but due to the demands of the job I spent most of my summer up here in the Bay rather than at home with my family.

job_title: Instructional Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Highly supportive and understanding faculty members in the English Department, who are definitely experts in their fields Work is on your schedule, as long as it gets done in a timely manner With only a one semester commitment, allows you to decide whether or not you want to continue being a paid grader in subsequent semesters during your graduate program Getting paid for work that is directly related to your academic studies is amazing, but realistically, the benefit of being an ISA is more for your CV, resume, and education than the pay itself, for most graduate students
cons: Sometimes it is very clear, even at the graduate student level, that the university administration undervalues the English Department The 4.5 hours per week maximum, while understandable, minimizes the financial support you can actually receive from being an ISA If you are committed to providing the best experience possible to the undergraduate students in your class, as most ISAs are, you will likely find yourself (completely voluntarily) working more than the 4.5 hours per week more often than not, but without getting paid for it

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Co-workers become family but only because there is so much misery in that place that everyone sticks together in order not to drown in sadness.
cons: Management is horrible. SFSU will never hire who is most qualified but who they can get for the lowest salary and that includes management. Many departments hire students to do the jobs of the actual workers but everyone looks the other way. The students are there to help but many are given projects that they are reponsible for beginning to end and should be given the credit for project but never  are given the credit. Students are afraid to complain because they don't want to lose their jobs. Also, good luck to you if you need a raise because you will never see it, unless your V.P. or manager really, really likes you otherwise it will be "Hello, foodstamps!". Another dirty secret is that SFSU pays it workers so poorly that many are on foodstamps.

review_title: Great place to work if you lack ambition.  If you have ambition, you will be frustrated.
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits for employees due to strong union.  Job security.
cons:
The problem with the best reasons to working at SF State is that it also causes the downside for working at SF State.  The fact that people have job security, many people do not feel motivated to work.  A select few people work hard, but they are motivated by internal factors, rather than external factors.  Many of the Senior Management are educators and not managers and try to impose their own ideologies or will upon the rest of the group, rather than doing what's best for the University and the students.  There is as much, if not more, movement towards protecting faculty than securing student's welfare and education.  

It's a completely broken system that encourages incompetence and laziness than excellence and diligence.

review_title: San Francisco State - good place to work
job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: As a student assistant, my schedule was flexible and I was able to adjust my hours according to my class schedule.  The department I worked in had a very friendly and open environment.  My supervisors encouraged open communication and I felt that the people in my dept really cared about each other.  It was very nice to have the monthly birthday parties and for the managers to acknowledge all the efforts we put into our work.
cons: The hourly pay was barely above minimum wage.  HR takes a very long time to process employment applications.  A lot of times, HR will send out postcards to acknowledge receipt of applications several months after you've applied.  It's kind of a given that someone else was hired after a few months, so there's really no point in sending out those postcards.

review_title: Solid learning experience, as long as you are working in tech.

You learn new skills here, and how to work with people of different ranks and personalities at the University. This is a great launchpad for students looking to get into tech and project management.
cons: You have a lot of superiors who are here to help, but there is a lot you have to teach yourself too. There's always something that is pressing for management to do so you may feel like you're not getting enough attention. But that's only because they are trying to help all students! Ask for help, and you will get it. Management will not baby you.

cons: Many of the clients we worked with simply had no idea of how much work went into preparing their events and would often ask for complicated set ups at the very last minute. Part of the job was translating the equipment setups to people with little or know knowledge of audio.

review_title: Labor violations, Weigarten Act violation, constructive discharge
job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: I thought it would have been a better environment since I was an alum. I was wrong.
cons: I experienced constructive discharge where my coworkers sabotaged my work and was not given the proper representation when I was being presented with discipline procedures immediately after I had a panic attack following a hostile verbal attack form one of the students. My job security was threatened and the Labor Employee rep forced me to undergo a Fitness for Duty exam. I was put on admin leave and forced to live without an income for six months while not being allowed back to my secretarial position. All of the procedures used were in violation of labor law, which I should have reported to the NLRB. NOTE the NLRB has a short time for the statute of limitations.

review_title: Student Assistant at the SFSU J. Paul Leonard Library
job_title: Teacher's Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: They are quite flexible with your schedule since you're a student. It's incredibly convenient since it's on-campus. You get great vacation times since the library is closed for at least a week during winter break, if not more, and even when it's open during holiday times, they don't need as much staff so you can easily take the time off. You get really familiar with everything the library has to offer students so you can take advantage of it yourself. You work with others students. A lot of the library staff is quite friendly and helpful. Depending on who you're working with, you may get free printing resources. The people who help you with your paperwork and give you your paychecks are incredibly friendly and understanding. Liz is particularly helpful! And both work/study and non-work/study students can work here.
cons: You never really know who your boss is since there are five different people who tell you what to do, and they often tell you very different things. No training implemented, so the other student assistants have to take the time to teach you how to do the job while you're in the midst of working. A lot of students aren't aware of their rights, i.e. the California mandatory break laws, FYI -- you get breaks mandated by the state of California, and the library purposely doesn't tell you to take breaks. No system for moving up. No co-worker group activities outside of work to meet the other people who work at the library -- they do this for all the other library staff, but student assistants are never invited, which is quite insulting. No benefits, student assistants should get free print cards or something. Management also greatly changed over time at this place. Richard was the best! But he's retired, so other people are trying to fill his very big shoes, and they're struggling. Since it's a government-owned entity, they don't have to pay the San Francisco minimum wage, but it's hard to ask them to pay more when budget cuts keep making everything more difficult for public universities. At least they pay more than the state minimum. Also, they pay once per month, which is a little too long in-between paychecks.
